p: Other important mechanisms for development and spread of resistant bacteria have been recently emphasized. For example, many bacteria and fungi have the ability to form biofilms by both free living and pathogenic species, thereby limiting local antibiotic penetration [ 5]. Chronic infection in rhinosinusitis, purulent ulcers, and cystic fibrosis seem to be due to biofilms in large part [ 2•]. As another example, Pseudomonas aeruginosa resistance to fluoroquinolones may be induced by diltiazem, a commonly used calcium channel blocker [ 2•].
